newsitem.title: UK: WORLD BONDS - Hard to lose on EMU convergence plays.
newsitem.headline: WORLD BONDS - Hard to lose on EMU convergence plays.

text.p: European convergence plays should be part of every bond investor's portfolio after this weekend's meeting of European finance officials, analysts said on Monday.
The meeting gave a single European currency a major boost and will drive the bonds of high-yielding countries like Italy, Sweden and Spain closer still to the European core.
Investors would be unwise to buck the trend, they said.
"Even though it looks an expensive game, it's still the only real game to play for outperformance in Europe," said David Brown, chief European economist at Bear Stearns in London.
The weekend gathering of finance ministers and central bankers at Dublin Castle brought European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) a big step closer to reality, anlaysts said.
Not only did finance ministers give their political commitment to a single currency starting in 1999, but they also began to hammer out the mechanics.

Ministers agreed a stability pact designed to ensure fiscal discipline once EMU begins, a new exchange rate mechanism (ERM II) linking the euro to those outside, and greater legal certainty for banks and businesses running up to 1999.
The meeting crowned a week of supportive developments for convergence trades, Brown said.
The Netherlands, France, and Sweden all presented 1997 budgets designed to bring their deficits to within the three percent deficit-to-GDP target required under EMU.
Meanwhile, the French franc confirmed its recovery after the pre-budget bruising it had suffered since August and the mark continued to retreat on the other European crosses, Brown said.

"The litmus test to the health of convergence near-term really comes from the franc," Brown said. "The fact that it quite clearly got itself out of jail last week...has given another reassuring nudge to sentiment in Europe."
The mark hit a three-and-half-month low against the franc on Monday at 3.3845/50 on the back of the weekend's negotiations.
With European interest rate unlikely to move dramatically higher any time soon, there is little to lose, analysts said.

Brown forecast the spread between 10-year Italian and German bond yields will shrink to 225 basis points by the end of 1996 from 283 currently, the Spanish/German gap to 150 from 185 and the Swedish/German gap to under 100 from 147.
Juli Collins-Thompson, economist at Yamaichi International in London, said Italian bonds faced a potentially tense week.

September inflation data due out in the next two days would be supportive, but the 1997 budget -- expected by the end of the week -- may cause problems. The Communist Refoundation Party was expected to fight proposed cuts in health and pension spending.
"(The market) has priced in an awful lot of good news and if we see any sort of resurgence of political problems the market will correct," said Collins-Thompson.
She forecast the Italian/German spread will widen to 330 basis points in the short-term but saw 250 by next year.
Adrian Owens, European economist at Julius Baer Investments, said British gilts -- not widely regarded as a convergence candidates -- offer value at their current 180 basis points.
"If we get a Labour victory at the next election and they decide to move ahead...then of course the UK yield is going to move in sharply," he said.
He also said for investors wishing to remain within the European core, there was value to be had at short ends.
The yield spread between two-year French and German bonds is currently trading at 48 basis points.
"If you think EMU is going to go ahead in two years' time, there's a chance that spread will come down to zero," he said.
More tantalising, however, was the Italian/German two-year spread, currently at 438 basis points and set to shrivel as Italian interest rate cuts eventually come through, he said.
